column57: neurological/functional/behavioral assessment, sensory testing, bladder function
column58: BBB scale, grid walk test, footprint analysis, girdle test, Von Frey test, bladder function
column60: blader function: amount of urine retained in the bladder in ml/day of retained urine; BBB: open field (a galvanized stock tank that was 105 cm in diameter with 30 cm high walls) for 4 min, 22-point scale, scale ranging from complete paralysis to normal locomotion, assesses hind limb joint movements, stepping, trunk position and stability, forelimb-hindlimb coordination, paw placement, toe clearance and tail position, 2 observers, one observer for each side; gridwalk test: videotaped on a metal grid walk 1.2 m long with 25 mm between grids. The number of instances that the hindpaws dropped below the plane of the grid was counted. To calculate the gridwalk failure %, the number of errors was divided by the total of steps multiplied by 100; footprint analysis: hindpaws were dipped in ink before ambulating down a 90 cm runway. Stride length on each side and stride width between two sides were calculated; girdle test: Allodynia was assessed by mechanically stimulating 13 points on the rat's trunk with a 5.46 mN von Frey hair. Rats do not normally vocalize to this stimulus, and vocalization is considered a sign of allodynia, rats were tested for 10 trials. The percent response was calculated as number of responses/total number of test sites multiplied by 100; Plantar Von Frey: Tactile sensitivity on the feet was assessed using different size von Frey filaments. Rats were placed in the testing chamber with wire mesh floors for 30 min prior to testing. The von Frey filament was brought into contact with the palms of each paw and then pressure was applied until the filament bent or the rat withdrew its paw, Mechanical threshold measurements for each paw were obtained at the end of the all procedures prior to perfusion.
column61: bladder function: daily until 21 days post injury; BBB: prior to injury and once weekly for seven weeks post-injury; gridwalk test: Pre-injury testing occurred 5 and 6 days prior to injury in Experiment 1, 1 and 2 days prior to injury in Experiment 2, and 11 and 12 days prior to injury in Experiment 3. Post-injury testing occurred prior BDA tract tracing (29–30 days post-injury in Experiments 1 and 2 and 27 days post injury in experiment 3). A final test was run before perfusion (43 days post-injury in Experiments 1 & 2 and 37–41 days post-injury in Experiment 3); footprint analysis: Pre-injury testing occurred 1 and 2 days prior to injury in Experiment 1, 4 and 5 days prior to injury in Experiment 2, and 5 and 6 days prior to injury in Experiment 3. Post-injury testing occurred prior BDA tract tracing (26-27 days post-injury in Experiments 1 and 2 and 29 days post injury in experiment 3). A final test was run prior to perfusion 40–41 days post-injury in Experiments 1 & 2 and 38–42 days post-injury in Experiment 3); gridle test: at the end of the testing period prior to perfusion; Plantar Von Frey: at the end of the all procedures prior to perfusion
column65: BBB and subscores: no significant difference between treatment and control group; grid walk task: no significant difference between treatment and control group; footprint analysis: for experiment 1=rats treated with ibuprofen had a narrower base support during ambulation signifying increased hindlimb motor control, but there was no significant difference in the stride length, no difference in either for experiment 2 and 3 or combined; von frey filament testing: no significant differences in withdrawal thresholds between ibuprofen and saline-treated groups in any of the individual experiments; gridle test: no significant differences between treatment groups in any of the individual experiments; bladder function:  no differences between treatment groups in the amount of retained urine in any experiment or in the combined data

column71: Avorstatin significantly reduced the early inflammatory response and sharply decreased the expression of caspase-3 in neurons, astrocytes, and oligodendrocytes 24 h post-SCI.
column72:
Anesthesia: Isoflurane (2-4%)
Antibiotic drug Amoksiklav (Sandoz Pharmaceuticals, Ljubljana, Slovenia; 30 mg/kg, i.m.) and the analgesic drug Novasul (Richterpharma, Wels, Austria; 2 mL/kg, i.m.) for three days
column73: Atorvastatin (5 mg/kg, i.p.) injected in a single dose immediately after spinal cord trauma, significantly reduced the early inflammatory response and sharply decreased the expression of caspase-3 in neurons, astrocytes, and oligodendrocytes 24 h post-SCI. Acute ATR treatment effectively prevented the excessive infiltration of destructive M1 macrophages around the lesion site, while the infiltration of beneficial M2 macrophages was less affected. This statin significantly improved the regeneration capacity of the injured tissue at six weeks, leading to the promotion of axonal outgrowth and increasing neurofilament expression. We can conclude that the early modulation of the inflammatory response via effects on the M1/M2 macrophages and the inhibition of caspase-3 expression strongly promote tissue regeneration in later periods.

There were fewer ED1-positive macrophages or microglia in the AA-100 group than in the control and AA-200 groups (Figure 3C)
column72: anesthesia: 2% isoflurane; postop: Cefotiam hydrochloride (40 mg/kg) and acetaminophen syrup (10 mg/kg) were administered to all operated rats for three days to prevent bacterial infection and control postoperative pain; euthanasia: deeply anesthetized and transcardially perfused with 200 mL 0.9% normal saline followed by 4% paraformaldehyde
column73: Administration of ascorbic acid (100 mg/kg) to SCI rats enhanced 5hmC levels; increased the expression of the Tet1, Tet2, and Tet3 genes within the brain motor cortex; promoted axonal sprouting within the lesion cavity of the spinal cord; and enhanced recovery of locomotor function until 12 weeks. In conclusion, we found that epigenetic status in the brain motor cortex is changed after SCI and that epigenetic modulation using ascorbic acid may contribute to functional recovery after SCI

column4: Assessment of Depression in a Rodent Model of Spinal Cord Injury
column11: Out of scope: no comparison between treatment vs non treatment but depression vs non depression instead
column45: laminectomy + contusion (MASCIS device, 10-g impactor outfitted with a 2.5mm tip, dropped from 12.5mm, wound was closed using Michael clips)
column53: from day 14 to day 32 post injury
column58: BBB scale, nociceptive reactivity (tail-flick test and von Frey stimulation, tactile reactivity)
column60: BBB: 21-point scale, 0= nomovement of the hindlimb (ankle, knee or hip), 14 = consistent weight-supported stepping with consistent forelimb/hindlimb coordination, 99cm diameter, 23cm deep, allowed to move freely, acclimated 5 ming on 3 consecutive days before surgery, observed for 5 min by 1 observer; tail-flick test: thermal reactivity was tested using a halogen light that was focused onto the rat’s tail, latency to flick the tail away from the radiant heat source (light) was recorded, 2 tests at 2-min intervals; von Frey stimulations: Filaments of increasing strength were applied every 2 sec in sequence to the plantar surface of the paw. The stimuli were presented until subjects exhibited a paw withdrawal/motor and vocalization response. The intensity of the stimuli that produced the responses was reported using the formula provided by Semmes-Weinstein: Intensity = log10 (10,000 * g force); tactile reactivity with girdle test: A von Frey hair with a bending force of 204.14 mN (26g force) was then applied to each point on the grid, and vocalization responses were recorded and mapped onto a grid map of that animal. Because animals do not normally vocalize with this stimulus, a vocalization response indicates that a noxious stimulus was experienced. In mapping the area of response, the number of vocalizations are recorded (Nv) and normalized by the following formula: [Nv · 100]/total number of applications (44), indicating the percent vocalizations out of the total number of applications

column60: vermicelli handling test: rats individually placed in home-cages and allowed to eat three pieces of 7-cm long uncooked vermicelli for each 10-minute trial, data were recorded as the number of ipsilateral paw adjustments made per vermicelli piece averaged over three trials with adjustments defined as any grasp-regrasp motion or movement of the digits; horizontal ladder test: horizontal ladder was 129 cm long and 16.5 cm wide with rungs inserted 2.5, 3.2, or 5.7 cm apart, rung positioning was varied weekly to prevent animals from learning the rung spacing pattern, categorized as: correct placement, touch, slip, or miss, percentage of correct placements [(#correct/(#correctþslipþmiss))*100]; CatWalk gait analysis: glass walkway (109 *15*0.6 cm) with dark plastic walls (109*8 cm) spaced 15 cm length apart in a darkened room, light from an encased fluorescent bulb was internally reflected within the glass walkway and scattered when the plantar surface of the paw contacted the walkway floor, thereby producing paw prints, the parameter analyzed, maximum paw print area, is defined as the area of the ipsilateral forepaw at maximal contact.
column61: vermicelli handling test: prior to SCI and on post-SCI day 6 and then every 7th day thereafter for the duration of the study. horizontal ladder test: prior to SCI and on post-SCI day 8 and then every 7th day thereafter for the duration of the study; CatWalk gait analysis: prior to SCI and on post-SCI day 9 and then every 7th day thereafter for the duration of the study.

column73: In conclusion, the results of the present study indicate that iNOS is induced in the early stages of SCI, leading to increased nitration of protein tyrosine residues and potentiation of inflammatory responses. Microglial cells appear to be the main cellular source of iNOS in SCI. In addition, nicotine-induced anti-inflammatory effects in SCI are mediated, at least in part, by the attenua-tion of iNOS over expression through the receptor-mediated mechanism.

column60: ladder walk test: placed at the bottom of the ladder which included 40 steps (20 mm intervals), foot faults for the left forepaw were counted during continuous steps, trained for 1 week (each for 10 min) before injury, correct placing, an incomplete placing and a missed bar were counted 11,0.5 and 00.5 and 0, respectively; EMG: electrode SC on the extensor digitorum muscle, stimulation of the radial nerve with 2 responses (M-wave from direct activation) and H-reflex from monosynaptic activation), amplitudes of the M- and H-waves as determined by the peak-to-peak values of each waveform were used to calculate the average Hmax/M ratio, latencies of the responses were measured as time elapsed between trigger and peak of each waveform, Hmax/M ratio at 1, 5 and 10 Hz was expressed as a percent of the Hmax/M ratio, at the baseline frequency of 0.3 Hz, in order to calculate the H-reflex rate depression; physiological reflexes: After a one-hour rest period after recording the H-reflex, to elicit electrically-induced muscle fatigue (EIF), rhythmic muscle contractions were produced by a neurostimulator, Fatigue was assessed from the decay of force throughout the 3-min EIF period. The strength of muscle contraction (the decay of force) was measured from the beginning to the end of this 3-min muscle electrical stimulation, Changes in ventilatory activity after EIF was expressed in percent [Dcycle/min (%)] of the mean cycles recorded two minutes before muscle stimulation

The fibreoptic beam had an exit-point power of 0.82 watts per cm^2)
column51: 15 min before or after SCI (2 groups)
column58: unprompted walking motor score, inclined plane test, sensory blockade (heat), somatosensory evoked potentials
column60: walking motor score: 0=normal walking, increments by 10 points until 50=no movements of the hindlimbs, 30=Vigorous and/or frequent movements of the hindlimbs, 1 observer, no stimulation on a smooth horizontal plane for 3 minutes; inclined plane: score by 10 point increments, from 0= > 65 degress to 30 = <35 degrees, rat on a plane which was horizontal initially, then successively tilted 5° every 30 sec and noting the angle at which the rat lost its balance; sensory score: withdrawal of hind paws during contact with a hot plate at 90°C, cut-off time was fixed at 20 sec to prevent thermal injury, three types of response to this test: Y (yes) for adapted withdrawal, N (no) for absence of withdrawal, or H for hyperactive flexion, equivalent to a liberated spinal reflex, sympathetic blockade was considered to exist if the animal had voiding dysfunction; SEPs: protocol of Baskin et al, right sciatic nerve was exposed and stimulated, anode was inserted in the somatopic area, two hundred responses with an acquisition time of 120 msec were averaged, SEP were analyzed for latencies (P1: first positive deflection, N1: first negative deflection, and P2: second positive deflection) and amplitudes (P1N1 and P2N2))
column61: motor function, inclined plane, sensory: 1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 12, 15, 18 days after lesion; SEP: day 18 after injury
column65: motor score: treatment before SCI made motor score better starting day 3 until end compared to control, treatment after made score better from day 3 to day 9 included but then no difference with control group, inclined plane: both treatment were better than control from day 3 to day 15 included but not on day 18, sensory function: no significant difference in these values among the three groups at any time; SEPs: Latencies were longer in the control group than in the treated groups, when treatment before injury difference in latency reached statistical significance except for N1 (first negative deflection), in group treated after lesion onthe the onset and P1 (first positive deflection) were significantly shorter than in the control group, SEP amplitudes were significantly higher inboth treatment groups than in the control group

column65: BBB: etomidate alone not significantly different from trauma only group at 24h and 72h, EPO alone and EPO+etomidate significantly better than traum only group both at 24h and 72h after injury; SEPs: no signficant difference between etomidate alone, or EPO alone or EPO+etomidate compared to trauma only group respectively
column67: lesions detected after the study were ranked in three groups as mild, moderate and severe
column71: Demyelinated areas, axonal degeneration and gliosis were detected partly in varying severity; no real comparison between groups; etomidate alone at 24h classified as moderate whilst control at 24th classified as severe (one image for each group)
column72: anesthesia: 60 mg/kg ketamine and 10 mg/kg xylazine, both IP; postop: gentamicin sulphate to prevent urinary infection (5 mg/kg/day, IP), 2 ml 0.9% NaCl SC to all animals after surgery to prevent dehydratation; euthanasia: general anesthesia and cervical dislocation
column73: The neuroprotective activity of etomidate was suspect. The neuroprotective effect of etanercept and erythropoietin after SCI was shown in individual and combined applications in this study. However, more experimental studies are needed for clinical use.

column4: Effect of combined treatment with melatonin and methylprednisolone on neurological recovery after experimental spinal cord injury
column23: 6 groups, 1 sham (n=6), other 5 groups n=18
column45: laminectomy + weight drop contusion (dura left intact, impact of 50 g/cm to the dorsal surface of the spinal cord)
column58: motor evoked potentials (MEP), cortico somatosensory evoked potentials (CSEP), motor function scale (modified Gale), inclined plane test
column60: CSEP: left sciatic nerve was isolated and stimulated with a pair of hook electrodes, duration of stimuli was 0.2 ms at 3 pps and the stimulus amplitude of each test was at a threshold sufficient for moving the ipsilateral foot, tests were performed twice each time and in each test 400 CSEP were averaged in an analysis time of 50 ms, The latency of CSEP was measured from the onset of the first negative deflec tion from the baseline. The amplitudes were measured from the distance between the first negative and positive peaks; MEPs: Two silver screw electrodes were placed epidurally over the right motor cortex area and on the hard palate as active and reference electrodes, respectively, to achieve transcortical stimulation by applying square wave pulses of 0.1 ms at 3 pps, recorded from 2 pairs of electrodes on the left sciatic nerve, motor response averaged with a sweep of 50 ms, performed twice, the latency of MEP was measured from the onset of the first positive or negative deflection from the baseline and the amplitude was measured between the positive and negative peaks of averaged waveforms, the waveforms obtained from the sciatic nerve represented the motor conduction velocity rather than motor unit potentials as measured from the innervated muscle; motor function scale: slight modification of the moto score proposed by Gale et al, open field 0.7*0.9m, observed at least 1 min, movement of hips, knees and ankle joints recorded, inclined plane test: rislin and tator's angle board test, max angle at which an animal can support its weight on an inclined plane measures in degrees from 0 to 90, animals places transversely and highest angle a rat can maintain for 5s recorded and described as capacity angle
column61: 4h. 10h and 10 days (3 different groups)
column65: MEP and CSEP: day 1- significantly longer mean latencies and lower amplitudes in the trauma group in comparison with MP, melatonin, and MP+melatonin groups, no difference in latency or amplitude between ethanol and control group, day 10- ethanol and trauma groups had significantly longer mean latencies and lower mean amplitudes of CSEP and MEP tests than those of the MP, melatonin, and MP+melatonin groups; motor function score: significant gradual recovery rate was observed in the rats treated with MP, melatonin, and MP+melatonin (P<0.05), [not clear if this is a comparison between treatment and SCI alone group]; inclined plane test: Trauma produced a highly significant decrease in angle score which, then, gradually recovered over a period of 10 days in the rats treated with MP, melatonin, and MP+melatonin (P<0.05). There was no significant increase in angle score for the rats in the trauma group (P>0.05).
column67: ultrastructural examination: each sample evaluated according to a grading system for quantitative evaluation, MDA levels
column71: ultrastructural findings support that melatonin, as well as MP, protects neurons, myelin, axons, and cytoplasmic organelles such as nucleus and mitochondrion, the evaluation according to the grading system showed the neuroprotective effects of melatonin, MP, and combined treatment
column72: anesthesia: chloral hydrate (400 mg/kg, IP); postop: All rats in the 10 days group received gentamicin twice daily during the first 3 days as prophylaxis against urinary tract infection; euthanasia: not reported
column73: MP, melatonin, and MP and melatonin combined treatment modalities improved functional recovery at the same level. Future studies involving different doses of melatonin and different dose combinations with MP could promise better results since each drug has a different anti-oxidative mechanism of action.
column74: tested only one dose of melatonin
column75: unclear to me if the motor function and inclined plane angles are actually compared between treatment and trauma only group so marked it as mixed at the moment, use chloral hydrate and gentamicin

column4: The effects of systemically administered methylprednisolone and recombinant human erythropoietin after acute spinal cord compressive injury in rats.
column45: laminectomy + compression (transient extradural application of an aneurysm clip exerting a 0.6-N closing force on the spinal cord for 1 min)
column47: methylprednisolone (MP), recombinant human erythropoietin (EPO) and combination
column53: infusion for 30 min, then 8h infusion started 15 min after the first one
column54: MP: 1 bolus + 8h infusion; EPO: single bolus (1000 U group) or 1000 U/kg/day for 3 successive days for 3000 U/kg group
column60: placed in the center of a round tube of water (40-cm diameter) filled to a depth of 30 cm with a wire mesh ladder attached to the side, 0=neither hind limb was used for swimming and climbing out, 1=partial use of the hind limbs, 2=both hind limbs used normally
column61: 24 and 72h after injury
column65: all treatment groups had significantly better neurological deficit grade at 24 and 72h compared to control group (trauma only), 2 time points not assessed separately but pulled
column67: number of ischemic neurons with histological characteristics of abnormal structures counted, presence and relative abundance of ischemic neurons in ventral gray matter area classified in 3 grouops: mild (5% of motor nuerons ischemic), moderate (5-20 %), severe (20% and more)
column71: MP alone not significantly different from control gorup, all other treatment groups were significantly better in terms of histopathological neuronal ischemic grade observed at 24 and 72h compared to control trauma only group (2 time points pooled)
column72: preop: imipenem (10 mg/kg of bw, IM) prophylaxis of infection; anesthesia: i.p. injection of thiopental sodium [40 mg/kg of body weight (bw)]; euthanasia: thiopental (120 mg/kg, i.p.)
column73: The results of these experiments demonstrate a major neurological benefit associated with the systemic administration of MPSS + rHu-EPO 3,000 U after TSCI produced by transient compression.
column75: pooled the results of 2 time points 24 and 72h after injury, suspect that it is due to low sample size (8 per group)

column4: Pregabalin as a neuroprotector after spinal cord injury in rats
column23: 1 control and 3 treatment groups, all n=8
column45: laminectomy + weight drop contusion (New York University (NYU) impactor, 10 g rod dropped from a height of 2.5 cm: 25 g-cm lesion)
column54: at 30 min and every 12 h for post-operative 2 days postoperatively
column58: motor function score (modified Gale), inclined plane test
column60: motor function socres: move freely, 1 observer, 1 min, recorded hip, knee and ankle joint movements, 0=no movement of the hindlimbs, 6=normal walking; inclined plane test: maintain its position on a board, which is raised in increments of 5°, index of hindlimb strength, max angle at which a rat was able to maintain its position for at least 5 s, was defined as the inclined plane score
column61: motor function score: daily; inclined plane test: 7 days after SCI
column63: motor function score: yes, inclined plane test: not reported
column65: motor function score: mean motor function scores of the control and GP groups were also significantly different (P = 0.01), no direct comparison between MP and control and MC and control; inclined plane: Comparing the inclined plane scores between control and GP group, there was also a statistical significance (P = 0.01), no direct comparison between MP and control and MC and control
column67: cystic lesions, TUNEL assay
column71: cyst sizes were greater in the control group than in the other three groups, no statistical analysis performed (acknowledged); TUNEL positive cells were signitficantly numerous in the control group than in the other 3 groups (p<0.05)
column72: anesthesia: ketamine (50 mg/kg) and rompun (2 mg/kg, i.p.); postop: 5 mg gentamycin IM; euthanasia: deep anesthesia by administering ketamine and rompun i.p, transcardiac perfusion was performed with 100 ml of buffered saline followed by 500 ml of 4% paraformaldehyde
column73: This experiment demonstrates that GP can act as a neuroprotector after SCI in rats, and its anti-apoptotic and anti-inflammatory effects are related to its neuroprotective effect
column75: use gentamicin, ketamine

column60: BBB: 21-point open-field; inclined plane test:  flat plane surface with their body axis parallel to the plane and were required to maintain their body position on the plane for 5 s for 3 of 5 attempts, if a rat was able to maintain its position for 3 trials, the angle of the plane was subsequently increased at increments of 5◦ until the rat failed to maintain its position; grip strength meter: animals were held by the hindlimbs and lower abdomen and drawn backward at a consistent speed within reach of a metal rung connected to the strength apparatus, strength meter measures the maximal force achieved when the grip was broken, strength was averaged over 5 successful grasps; tail flick test: wrapped in a blanket while the tail was left exposed to a beam of light, which served as a heat source, the time elapsed before the rat ‘flicked’ its tail in response to heat was recorded; CatWalk: successful performance required three complete crossings with at least three consecutive step cycles for analysis, paw prints labeled

column65: BBB: hIgG (2 g/kg) demonstrated better hindlimb function (all groups), inclined plane test and grip strength meter: significant improvements for grip strength and trunk stability began at 4 weeks post SCI; gait analysis with CatWalk XT 10.6 multivariate system: quantifiable positive changes in gait as measured by the Noldus CatWalk system. Specifically, delayed administration of hIgG (2 g/kg) led to improvements in the regulatory index (a measure of interlimb coordination during gait), stride length (a measure of distance between two consecutive paw placements of the same paw) and swing speed (computed from stride length and swing duration), no improvements in the animal’s ability to maintain balance during movement or preferred paw usage during motion, as indicated by base of support and paw area, respectively; somatosensory evoked potentials (SSEPs) and tail flick test: no differences in pain sensation across all time points regardless of treatment groups,  delayed administration of hIgG (2 g/ kg) resulted in greater electrical activity in the brain due to tactile stimulation at the tibialis anterior.

Overall, tissue and neuronal preservation in animals treated with hIgG (2 g/kg) correlated with improved motor and sensory functions.

column45: partial laminectomy + crush (tips of deumont #2 tweezers so that each tip was 1 mm lateral of the midline and 2mm deep into the spinal cord parenchyma, spanning the gap between the dorsal root entries and keeping them closed for 20s)
column46: 8 weeks after injury (16 weeks after start of the experiment)
column50: 1–2 mg/kg (increased by 0.5 at week 3 and 5 post injury)
column53: 8 or 5 weeks (for 8 weeks: crossover between week 6 and 8 = buspirone-treated rats were switched to saline treatment while the saline-treated rats were switched to a buspirone treatment)
column58: grasping test (food retrieval), horizontal ladder task, spinal motor–evoked potentials (sMEPs)
column60: reaching and grasping task: grasping attempt was subdivided into seven stages (advance, digit extension, arpeggio, grasp, supination I, supination II, and release), trained to reach through the window, grasp the pellet, and retrieve the pellet to its mouth for a period of 10 min or until they achieved a maximum of 20 attempts per session, A successful trial for the reaching task was scored when the rat was able to reach, grasp, and eat the pellet. Cases in which the rat made an error in reaching, grasping, or eating were scored as failures, success rate was calculated by counting the number of successful trials per session and expressed as a percentage of total trials, success rates were normalized to pre-injury scores; horizontal ladder test: ladder (1 m long) consisted of side walls made of clear Plexiglas and fitted metal rungs (3 mm diameter) that could be irregularly spaced at distances ranging from 1 to 3 cm, two templates of irregular rung patterns were alternated every other week during testing. Steps from both forelimbs were categorized as 1=miss, in which the paw was placed in between two rungs and did not make contact with any rungs before falling between the rungs, disturbing body posture and balance, 4= correct placement, in which the mid-portion of the paw was placed on a rung with full weight support and the digits curved around the rung. Misses and slips were considered as footstep errors. Error rates were calculated by counting the number of footstep errors per category and expressed as the average rate per trial; EMG: Monophasic and bipolar epidural stimulation (2 Hz) at spinal cord levels C6 and C8 was used to evoke potentials in selected forelimb muscles of the preferred forelimb at different current intensities using a constant current stimulator, monitoring of sMEPs
column61: once per week from week 1 to 8 post injury
column65: buspirone group performed significantly better in reaching and grasping compared to control group, fluoxetine group performed significnatly better than control as well in the fixed doses regimen; horizontal ladder walking test: not significantly different in both treatments groups compared to control group; EMGs:  By 6 wpi, there were distinct differences in EMG patterns between saline- and buspirone-treated rats, mixed results for Integrated EMG in buspirone treated animals compared to controls, amplitude and AUC of sMEPs to the same stimulation parameters were significantly reduced in saline-treated animals but more sustained in buspirone-treated animals
column72: postop electrodes: subcutaneous injections of buprenorphine (0.05 mg/kg) for pain relief before recovering from anesthesia and every 12 h for 3 days after surgery, together with 2.5 mg/kg antibiotic Baytril and 0.6 ml of lactated Ringer’s, subcutaneously; anesthesia SCI: not reported; euthanasia: perfused with 4% paraformaldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate-buffered solution (PBS)
column73: both serotonergic drugs, buspirone and fluoxetine, neuromodulated these networks to physiological states that enabled markedly improved forelimb function after cervical spinal cord injury
column75: could not find the histological results, treatment regimen not so straight forward, use buprenorphine

This effect correlated with the ability of DEX to accelerate behavioral recovery of function measured by a combined behavioral score. column4: Combination of methylprednisolone and rosiglitazone promotes recovery of neurological function after spinal cord injury.

Scores from 8 to 13 indicate return of paw placement and coordinated movements with the forelimbs. Scores from 14 to 21 show return of toe clearance during stepping, predominant paw position, trunk stability, and tail position. Scores are represented as the average score of all animals (n = 6) in each group at each time point.

column4: Sodium channel blockade with phenytoin protects spinal cord axons, enhances axonal conduction, and improves functional motor recovery after contusion SCI
column23: 4 groups in total, sham group with and without treatment both n = 6
column45: laminectomy + spinal contusion: MASCIS/NYU impact injury device (10g, 2.0mm diameter rod released from 25mm height, mean(SD) tissue compression: 2.11 (0.13) mm)
column58: BBB scale, foot print analysis (fine motor control), grid footfalls, compound action potential (CAP) recording
column60: BBB: 21-point ordinal scale ranging from 0 (no discernable hindlimb movement) to 21 (consistent and coordinated gait with parallel paw placement of the hindlimb and consistent trunk stability), 0 to 7 = early phase of recovery with return of isolated movements of three joints (hip, knee, ankle), 8-13 = intermediate recovery with return of paw placement, stepping and forelimb-hindlimb coordination, 14-21 = late phase of recovery measuring toe clearance during step pahse, paw positioning, trunk stability amd tail position; footprint analysis: animal’s hindpaws were inked and the animal was placed on anarrow (13*50 cm) runway,  5 inked tracing per animal, series of 3 incremental steps to determine mean values of base of support (distance between the central pads of the hindpaw), stride length (distance between two consecutive footprints on each side of the animal) and paw offset angle (angle formed by the intersection of lines from the left and right footprints relative to the animal’s direction of travel); grid footfalls: animals placed on the runway and allowed to cross to the opposite side (1 m), error = misplacement of the animal’s paw such that it fell through the grid and consequently below the plane of the floor, rather than being placed on the grid; CAP recording: stimulation of DC axons at L1–L2 and recording of CAP at T5–T6 at the surface of the midline spinal cord, single current pulses (0.05ms) were applied in increasing increments (0.2, 0.3, 0.6, 0.8, 1.1 mA), amplitude of CAP = value between the negative deflection after the stimulus artifact and the next peak of the wave, area of the CAP = rectifying the CAP component (full-wave rectification) and measuring its area.
column61: BBB: every 2 days following injury; footprint analysis and grid footfalls: not reported; CAP: 4 weeks after injury
column63: CAP and BBB: yes, rest: not reported
column65: BBB: SCI + phenytoin group achieved significantly (P< 0.05) better performance than the SCI group; base of paw support: SCI + phenytoin group significantly (P< 0.05) less widened; stride length at 4 weeks: no significant difference between SCI and SCI + phenytoin groups, frequency distributions: SCI + phenytoin range of stride lengths was less variant when compared to SCI group; paw offset angle: SCI + phenytoin group exhibited rotation that was significantly (P< 0.05) reduced when compared to SCI; number of footfall errors: SCI + phenytoin group demonstrated fewer errors (35%), a significant (P< 0.05) difference when compared to SCI (72%);  CAP: SCI + phenytoin demonstrated significantly (P< 0.05, P< 0.01) larger CAP amplitudes at stimulation intensities greater than 0.6 mA, compared to untreated SCI. CAP area in SCI + phenytoin was significantly (P< 0.05) larger than in SCI
column67: spared tissue analysis, axonal sparing
column71: spared tissue analysis, SCI + phenytoin compared to SCI: less severe extent of tissue damage, white matter damage significantly reduced (epicenter and both rostral and caudal directions), gray matter significantly less damaged, total cord cross-sectional area increased, no difference in areas of cyst formation and gliosis; axonal sparing, SCI + phenytoin compared to SCI: degree of axonal loss was significantly less

column58: ASIA motor score, FIM motor score
column60: The first primary outcome was the discharge ASIA motor score. The ASIA motor score is a standardized examination based on a meticulously performed strength assessment, as defined by ISNCSCI. It is calculated by summating motor grades (0–5 scale) recorded for 5 upper limb and 5 lower limb muscles bilaterally. The ASIA motor score ranges from 0 to 100. The second primary outcome was discharge FIM motor score. The FIM assessment measures motor and non-motor domains of function: social cognition, communication, mobility, sphincter control, self-care, and locomotion. The FIM motor score component represents the sum of the 13 specific motor items of the FIM assessment. Each motor item has a maximal level score of 7. Total scores range from a minimum of 13 to a maximum of 91.
column61: at the time of hospital admission (for 75% of the patients), at rehabilitation admission (rehabilitation baseline scores), at discharge
column65: Adjusting for age, sex, weight, race, respective baseline motor score, surgical intervention, injury level, ASIA Impairment Scale (AIS) grade, education, and insurance status, there was no association with improvement in dis- charge ASIA motor function or FIM motor score among MP recipients: −0.34 (95% CI, −2.8, 2.1) and 0.75 (95% CI, −2.8, 4.3), respectively. Adjusting for age, sex, race, weight, injury level, and receipt of surgery, no association with increased risk of infection or GI complications was observed.
column72: no other drug reported
column73: This retrospective cohort study involving patients with acute TSCI observed no short-term improvements in motor function among MP recipients compared with nonrecipients. Our findings support current recommendations that MP use in this population should be limited.

column23: sham group, numbers recalculated based on number provided for each assessment
column41: level: T8-T9; severity: moderate to severe
column45: gonadectomy + laminectomy + compression (extradurally for 3 s)
column60: 1.2m diameter metal smooth-surfaced activity chamber, 4 min, two investigators, discrepancy discussed and scored to the deficit, score for each hindlimb and averaged, range from no movement (0) to normal walking with coordinated fore-hindlimb stepping and normal paw placement (21), used a transformation of the BBB scale developed specifically to improve the metric propertied in evaluation of animals with moderate to severe SCI
column61: 3, 7, 14, 21 and 28 days after injury
column65: In rats that received a gonadectomy prior to injury, post-SCI administration of either the 0.5- or 5.0-mg pellet of E2 significantly improved the BBB open-field scores on days 14, 21, and 28 compared to the group receiving the placebo (0.0 mg) pellet;  Similarly, in gonad-intact male rats, administration of the 0.5- or 5.0-mg pellet of E2 significantly improved the BBB open-field locomotor score compared to the placebo group on post-SCI days 7, 14, 21, and 28, and days 14, 21, and 28 respectively; no effect when 0.05-mg

A similar trend was seen in gonad-intact rats in that more neurons were visualized in the 0.5- and 5.0-mg treatment groups than in the placebo (0.0 mg) or 0.05-mg treatment groups; TUNEL positive significantly reduced with 0.5mg and 5.0mg treatment but not 0.05mg

column23: sham n = 6
column45: laminectomy + complete transection SCI induced by severing the spinal cord with a MicroFeather ophthalmic scalpel
column47: SWNT-PEG (single-walled carbon nanotubes with polyethylene glycol)
column50: acute administration: 10 microg/mL in 25 microL, 10 microg/mL in 50 microL; delayed administration: 25 microL with 1 microg/mL, 10 microg/mL or 100 microg/mL
column51: acute: 5 min after injury; delayed: 1 week after injury
column58: BBB test, kinematic analysis with the CatWalk gait analysis system, hindpaw withdrawal threshold for mechanical allodynia, tail-flick test
column60: BBB: range from 0 (no hindlimb movement) to 21 (no impairment in walking or gait), 1.2m-diameter metal smooth-surfaced activity chamber for 4 min, two investigators, discrepancies in scores were discussed and scored to the deficit, score for each hindlimb and averaged; kinematic analysis: glass walkway and a 60 Hz. camera digitally records the pawprints, gait analysed frame by frame; mechanical allodynia: stimulation with a series of calibrated von Frey filaments, stimulus of 2g, 4g, 6g, 8g, 15g, 26g, 60g to the plantar surface of the hindpaw while the animal stood on a wire grid, the lowest filaments receiving at least 50% positive response of 5 trials (at least 3 positive responses) was recorded as the conclusive sensitivity level using the up-down method, only animals with plantar placement evaluated; tail-flick test: radiant heat source of a tail-flick unit focused on the rat's tail 3-5cm from the tip, tail-flick latency measured in seconds by a timer connected to a photoelectric cell that upon movement of the tail stopped the timer and the heat, two trials and latencies were averaged
column61: BBB: pre-injury, once each week for the following 35 days; kinematic analysis: one day pre-injury, once every week for 35 days; mechanical alllodynia: not reported; tail-flick test: weekly evaluation
column65: delayed treatment: BBB: 100 microg/mL group had significantly higher BBB score ath day 35 compared to control; max hindpaw print area catwalk kinematic: 100 microg/mL group had trend toward increased max hindpaw print area but not significant, allodynia: no significant differences in tail-flick latency were observed between for any treatment (no increased sensibility to heat induced by high dose of treatment)

column69: lession volume and corticospinal tract axonal count: yes, others not reported

column72: postop care twice daily: isotonic saline (5 ml SC BID), enrofloxacin (5 mg/kg SC QD), carprofen (1 mg/kg SC BID) for 7 days post-op; euthanasia: overdose of pentobarbital and perfused with 4% paraformaldehyde
column73: post-SCI administration of SWNT-PEG decreased lesion volume, increased neurofilament-positive fibers and corticospinal tract fibers in the lesion, and did not increase reactive gliosis; post-SCI administration of SWNT-PEG induced a modest improvement in hindlimb locomotor recovery without inducing hyperalgesia; suggest that SWNT-PEG may be an effective material to promote axonal repair and regeneration after SCI

column4: Intrathecal Administration of Melatonin Ameliorates the Neuroinflammation-mediated Sensory and Motor Dysfunction in a rat Model of Compression Spinal Cord Injury.
column23: sham n = 15
column45: laminectomy + aneurysm clip with a 90 g force for 60s
column58: BBB test, Von Frey test, acetone drop test, inclined plane test
column60: Von Frey test: increasing forces (10, 15, 26, 60 and 100 gram-forces), each filament was used five times on the palmar surface of the claw with 5 s intervals. The filament-induced paw withdrawal, flinching, biting, and licking were defined as positive responses. Three out of five stimuli were considered the threshold of allodynia as a positive response, both left and right paws were evaluated in response to the stimulation of filaments; acetone drop test: wire mesh network on an acrylic cage, 100 μL of acetone from a 2 cm distance, according to the drawback of the hind claw, responses were categorized and scored as (0) no paw withdrawal, (1) startle response without paw withdrawal, (2) slight paw withdrawal, (3) prolonged paw withdrawal (5-30 s), (4) repetitive and prolonged paw withdrawal (30 s) and (5) licking and flinching; BBB score: box with 90 cm2 surface and 10 cm surrounding walls for 5 min, scored in the range of 0 (hind limbs full paralysis) to 21 (normal walking), average scores of both left and right hind paws were determined per time point to obtain the average; inclined plane test: wood plane (60×40cm) capable of being inclined at the angles of 0° (horizontal) to 70°, biggest angle in which rats could stay for 5 s, was analyzed by two blinded observers, the mean angle was determined at the same time points.
column61: von frey: weekly till day 28; acetome drop test: not reported; BBB: before surgery and weekly till 28 days; inclined plane test: not reported
column65: von frey, BBB test, acetone drop test, inclined test all significantly better in the treatment group compared to control
column67: extent of spared myelin, mean of number of dorsal horn sensory neurons, spared myelin percentage (normal-myelinated tissue area  divided by the whole spinal cord area), mean survived sensory neurons on the gray matter of both dorsal horns
column71: MEL treatment significantly preserved the white matter normal staining and reduced myelin loss at different time points post-SCI (p < 0.05); MEL significantly improved the neuronal survival (p < 0.05 and p <0.01)
column72: anesthesia: keatmine (80 mg/kg), xylazine (10 mg/kg), ethanol 70% to disinfect instruments; postop: twice a day normal SC saline (2mL) to prevent dehydration, IP cefazolin to prevent infections (40 mg/kg)
column73: The results suggest melatonin as a promising candidate for medical therapies with advantageous effects on improving functional recovery through suppressing inflammatory mediators, and attenuating spinal tissue damages
column74: As no FDA approved drug has been so far introduced to be used as a positive control in such studies, our study has a minor limitation in this regard

column4: Intrathecal morphine attenuates recovery of function after a spinal cord injury

column45: laminectomy + weight drop (onto intact dura, MASCIS device, 10g impactor outfitted with a 2.5mm tip to drop 12.5mm)
column50: 0, 30 or 90 microg dissolved in 2 microL of distilled water followed by 20 microL of saline to flush the catheter
column58: BBB scale, ladder walk test, beam walk test, sensory function (paw withdrawal), nociceptive reactivity (thermal shock threshold tested through tail-flick test)
column60: BBB: open field, acclimated 5 min per day for 3 days prior to surgery, observed for 4 min, locomotor scores transformed to be amendable to parametric analyses (pooling of 2-4 and 14-21); ladder walk test: habituation 8 min per day for 3 days, cross a horizontal ladder (20cm wide, 37 rungs at 2.5cm spacing) to reach a black box, counted number of foot slips; beam walk: same habituation as ladder test, traverse a tapered beam (0.375-6.75 in wide), average width across the 2 legs was used as an index of beam walk performance; sensory/noiciception: incremented shock and radiant heat, time to paw withdrawal
column61: BBB: once per day for 1 week (days 2-7), every other day (days 9-15), every third day (18-21); ladder and beam test: end of 3-week after injury; sensory: day 21
column65: motor response to heat at acute stage: tail-flick lattency significantly increased in both treatment groups compared to control (negative effect); voice response to heat at acute stage: no significant difference between groups (no effect); motor response to shock at acute stage: no significant difference between groups (no effect); voice response to shock at acute stage: lattency to vocalize significantly increased in both treatment groups compared to control (negative effect); BBB: dose-dependant attenuation of locomotor recovery, high dose treatment group recovered significantly less motor function than control (negative effect); tapered beam and ladder walk tests: no significant difference between groups on beam walk (no effect), 30microg and 90microg group significantly different in ladder walk (more missteps for higher dose), but no comparison with control (difference seems not significant from plot) (no effect to negative effect?); no effect of morphine on either motor or vocal reactivity to mechanical stimuli, heat or shock stimuli assessed at 21 days (chronic stage)
column67: total cross-sectional area, spared tissue
column71: no effect of morphine at the lesion center, for any histological indice. The relative lesion (damage + missing), and areas of remaining gray and white matter were comparable across groups, no significant effects of drug dose were found caudal to the injury site; Morphine significantly affected the relative lesion area and the area of gray matter remaining rostral to the injury site. Although there was no main effect of dose on the relative lesion, there was a significant Dose􏰀*Section Level interaction (p < 0.05)
column72: anesthesia: isoflurane (5% gas), maintained with 2-3% isoflurane; infection prevention: penicillin G potassium (100'000 units/kg) immediately after surgery and again 2 days later; euthanasia: deep anesthesia (100 mg/kg pentobarbital, IP), perfused intracardially with 4% paraformaldehyde
column73: data presented here suggest that morphine given in the acute phase of a contusion injury, and particularly i.t. mor- phine, can severely compromise recovery of function at multiple levels
column75: higher mortality and autophagia with increasing doses of morphine

column4: Progesterone reduces secondary damage, preserves white matter, and improves locomotor outcome after spinal cord contusion
column23: sham n= 8
column41: level: T8; severity: moderate to severe contusion
column45: laminectomy + contusion (Infinite Horizon device, force of 200 Kdyn with no additional dwell time)
column58: BBB scale, Catwalk-automated quantitative gait analysis, mechanical sensitivity, thermal sensitivity
column60: BBB: 2 trained observers, 4 min, movement elicited by the touch of an examiner were not scored, 0=nomovement of the hindlimb, 21=normal locomotion as observed in unlesioned rats, score includes criteria such as joint movements, weight support, forelimb-hindlimb coordination and tail position, corrected open field BBB using objective assessments of coordination with the CatWalk system, CatWalk: 5 uninterrupted runs considering "consistent coordination" when regularity index scored 100% in 5/5 runs, to "no coordintation" when RI scored 100% in 0/5 runs, also sued the BBB subscoring scale to improve the sensitivity of the BBB by scoring the higher motor functions (toe clerance, predominant paw position, trunk stability andd tail position) regardless of the other BBB parameters, adding them together to yield a single score (max score of 13); CatWalk measures a large number of both static and dynamic gait parameters and enables quantitative assessment of locomotion, following criteria had to be met for walkway crossing: 1) rat crossed the walkway without any interruption or hesitation with a cosistent pace, 2) a minimum of five correct crossings with about four step cycle, 3) only runs with stable crossing time of the runway between3 nd 4 seconds were included, left and right gait parameters were averaged; sensory function: sugared cereal reward, average value of three readings was used as the tolerance trheshold for each hindpaw, mechanical sensitivity: dynamic plantar aesthesiometer, wire mesh floor over the stimulator unit, metal filament applied to the center of the palmar surface of the hindpaw, and upward force was increased from 1 to 50g over 15sec, force at withdrawal was recorded for both hindpaws, themarl sensitivity: plantar test according to Hargreaves method, light source positioned under center of palmar hindpaw, turn off when rat lift paw, 20-sec cutoff to prevent tissue damage, thermal withdrawal latency was recorded for both hindpaws
column61: BBB: 3,7,14,30 and 60 days after SCI (with CatWalk); CatWalk for gait analysis: before surgery, day 14, 30 and 60 after injury; sensory (mechanical reactivity, thermal sensitivity): 60 days after injury
column65: CatWalk-modified BBB and BBB subscores significantly better in treatment group compared to control, gait analysis: base support, stride length, duty cycle, swing significantly better in treatment group compared to group with SCI without treatment; coordination (regulatiry index, diagonal pairs, ipsilateral pairs, pelvic girdle) significantly better in treatment group compared to non treatment after SCI; neither progesterone nor SCI induced mechanical or thermal allodynia after 60 days of SCI
column67: quantification of axonal profiles: axonal preservation expressed as percentage of total axonal profile in white matter with respect to sham animals; tissue sparing; edema volume; total volume of spinal cord at the epicenter region
column71: increase in spred white matter preservation in treatment gorup compared to non treatment, progesterone increased the oligodendrocytes number and reduced myelin damage, improved axonal preservation compared to no treatment; no difference in spared grey matter,
column72: anesthesia: sodium pentobarbital (IP, 45 mg/kg) and xilagesic (2% xylazine, 10 mg/kg), atropine (50 microg/kg, low dose) to reduce salivary and bronchial secretions and to avoid the induction of bradycardia and possible acrdiac arrest by the surgery or xylazine, artifical tears to present corneal abrasion and infection ; postop: SC buprex (buprenorphine, 0.05 mg/kg) and proophylactic SC antibiotic injection 1h after lesion and on the following day (baytril, enrofloxacine, 1 mg/kg); euthanasia: anesthesized andthranscardially perfused with 4% paraformaldehyde in 0.1M PB)
column73: progesterone treatment significantly improved motor outcome as assessed using the Basso-Bresnahan-Beattie scale for locomotion and CatWalk gait analysis
column75: use pentobarbital, atropine

column4: Repeated systemic administration of morphine promotes recovery of locomotor function after spinal cord injury in rats
column45: laminectomy + compressive SCI (dura intact from laminectomy, spinal cord compressed from both lateral sides for 20s using a microvessel clip with a closing force of 8g)
column58: BBB scale, inclined plane test, tail-flick test, tactile sensory test with Von Frey filaments
column60: BBB: move freely for 4 min in an open field with a nonskid floor, score from 0 to 21 (complete hind limb paralysis to normal locomotion); inclined plane testL assess equilibrium and residual strength of fore and hind limbs, maintain position on a movable plane with a rough surface adjusted by 5 degrees increments to a max angle of 90 degrees, max angle that rat support weight for 5s recorded as the inclined plane score; tail-flick test: thermal nociceptive thresholds, dsital one-third of the tail immersed in water maintained at 52 +/- 0.5 degrees celsius, nociceptive endpoint was characteristic withdrawal of the tail from the warm water, an average of 3 consecutive trials separated by 5 min interval was designated the nociceptive threshold; Von Frey test: tactile sensory thresholds, hind paw plantar surface using a modified version of the up-down method, wire mesh floor and aclimate for 15 min before testing, 10 filaments applications used and 30-60s separated each touch, tactile sensory threshold was defined as the lowest gram force needed to produce hind paw withdrawal during at least 50% of its application
column61: BBB: prior to surgery and then 1, 7, 14, 21 and 28 days after SCI, inclined plane test: same as BBB; tail-flick and Von Frey tests: prior to surgery and day 28 after surgery
column65: BBB: significantly higher score starting day 7 until end of the experiment in morphine group compared to control group; inclined plane test: significantly higher score starting day 14 until end of the experiment in morphine group compared to control group; tail-flick test and tactiale sensory threshold: no significant difference between treated and controls after 28 days
column67: white matter sparing
column71: % of white matter sparing significantly higher in morphine group compared to control group
column72: anesthesia: sodium pentobarbital (50 mg/kg, IP); postop: 2 mL sterical saline IP; euthanasia: deeply anesthesized and transcardially perfused with saline followed by 4% paraformaldehyde
column73: observations suggest that repeated systemic administration of morphine during an acute stage of SCI promotes recovery of locomotor function without promoting development of hyperalgesia and allodynia.

column58: Von Frey testing, sciatic nerve stimulation
column60: Von Frey: plantar threshold was measured using retractable monofilaments (Ugo Basile) calibrated to deliver a target force spanning from 0.4 (normal) to 4 gr (diminished light touch). A quick withdrawal of the hind paw was considered as a positive response. Signs of supraspinal sensitization (i.e. sustained paw withdrawal and/or licking the paw) were also annotated. A pause of 20-30 sec was given to allow sensory receptors to reach baseline levels between each monofilament application. After 20 stimuli presentations, the lowest force, which produced a retraction at least 50% of the time, determined the response threshold; Sciatic nerve stimulation: left sciatic nerve was exposed at the mid-thigh level and electrically stimulated at 5 Hz for 5 min using a square pulse stimulator followed by a 5 min pause

column4: Treatment of rats with spinal cord injury using human bone marrow-derived stromal cells prepared by negative selection.
column23: very detailed in figure1
column45: laminectomy + contusion (impactor rod positioned centrally at T9-T10 over the spinal cord midline, contusion applied by pressing it against the dorsal surface of the tissue, when a force of 2N was reached the rod was immediately retracted [zero dwell time])
column58: BBB scale, rotarod locomotor function test, Von Frey test of mechanical allodynia/hyperalgesia
column60: BBB: scale from 0=no hind limb movement and 21=normal movements coordinated gait with parallel paw placement; 0-7=return of isolated movements in the trhee joints of hip knee and ankle, 8-13=return of paw placement and coordinated movements with the forelimbs etc; rotarod locomotor function test: required the rats to maintain their body on a rotating rod, 4 training session of 5 min each, constant speed of 5 rpm of the rotating rod, roataion speed accelerated from 5 rpm to 15 rpm over a period of 3 min, readout was the time that the rats were able to stay on the ratating rod before falling off (mean over 2 repetitions separated by at least 15 min); Von Frey test: rats placed in cages with wire mesh bottom, filament pressed perpendivularly to the plantar surface of the hind paw until it buckled and held for 2-5s, response considered positive if animal exhibited any nocifensive behavior such as a brisk withdrawal or licking of the paw, both hind paws stimulated and paw withdrawal threshold determined using the simplified up-down method
column61: BBB: pre-SCIm day 2, 4 after injury and then once per week for the next 9 weeks; Rotarod test: tao and 1 day before injury, day 4 and 7 after injury and then weekly; Von Frey test: before SCI and at the end of the 9 weeks observation period
column63: BBB: yes, Rotarod test: not reported, Von Frey test: not reported
column65: BBB: no significant difference between MP and control group at week 9, trend towards MP being worse than control (control significantly better at week 1 and 5, MP group average always below control group average); Rotarod test: no signficant difference between groups (high variability since lots of rats refused the test); Von Frey test: no hyperalgesia/allodynia in bmSC implanted animals, while this occurred in 1/5 rats treated with MP and 3/9 rats iin control group (no statistical test associated)
column67: max anterior-posterior extension fo the tissue lesion and the tissue loss in the lesion center

column72: anesthesia: 5% isoflurane/95% oxygen then 2.5% isoflurane via inhalation of a vaporizer, analgesic buprenorfine 0.05 mg/kg; after anesthesia: 2*2.5 mL isotonic saline SC, antibiotic marbofloxacine 5 mg/kg; postop: first 3 days, 2 daily SC injections of buprenorfine 0.05 mg/kg, SC 5 mg/kg marbofloxacine at day of surgery, day 2 and 4, if UTI marbofloxacine 5 mg/kg SC every 48h until urine clear and without blood; ethanasia: IP injection of 100 mg/kg sodium pentobarbital
column73: Human bmSC that were prepared by negative selection without expansion in culture have neuroprotective properties after SCI. column4: Treatment with immunosuppressants FTY720 and tacrolimus promotes functional recovery after spinal cord injury in rats
column23: 2 treatment groups not of interest, n = 12 each
column45: laminectomy + weight-drop contusion (10g-rod, 25mm height)
column58: BBB scale, inclined plane test, footprint analysis, somatosensory evoked potentials
column60: BBB: open-field, 0=flaccid paralysis, 21 = normal gait, 90cm diameter plastic wasing pool, 4cm height, averaged for each group; inclined plane test: max angle on the inclined plane upon which the animal can maintain a stable position for 5 sec, board incrementally raised to increase angles, angle scores averaged for each group; footprint analysis: walking patterns of the hindlimbs recorded with ink during continuous locomotion across a 90cm runway, stride length on each side and the stride width between the two sides were calculated, both were averaged per group; SSEPs: recorded on sensory cortex of the brain, subdermal electodes stimulated nerve impulses from the tibial nerves of both hindlimbs (trains in sets of 200 at 3Hz, stimulus amplitude 3mA squre wave, 200 micros in duration), active electrode into the interspinous ligament at T10, measures anplitude and latency of the evoked potentials, averaged per group
column61: BBB and inclined plane test: before surgery, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 , 35 and 42 days after surgery; footprint analysis: day 42; SSEPs: 21 and 42 days after injury
column65: BBB: Both the FTY720 + tacrolimus-treated group and the FTY720- and tacrolimus- treated groups showed significantly improved hindlimb performance compared to the saline-treated control group, FTY720 + tacrolimus-treated group demonstrated a higher mean BBB score (P < 0.05) than those of the FTY720- and tacrolimus-treated groups,  no statistical difference in mean BBB scores between the FTY720- and the tacrolimus-treated groups; inclined plane test: All three treatment groups demonstrated significantly higher mean angle scores than that of saline-treated control group, FTY720 + tacrolimus-treated group showed a higher mean angle score than those of the FTY720- and tacrolimus-treated groups, No differences in mean angle scores were observed between the FTY720- and the tacrolimus-treated groups; footprint analysis: greater mean stride length and a shorter mean stride width in FTY720 + tacroli- mus-treated group than in the other three groups, No differences were found in the mean stride width among the FTY720-, tacrolimus- and saline-treated control groups, significantly greater mean stride lengths in the FTY720- and the tacrolimus-treated groups than in the saline-treated control group; electrophysiology: FTY720-, tacrolimus- and FTY720 + tacrolimus-treated groups showed significantly higher (P < 0.05) mean amplitude and shorter (P < 0.05) mean latency of SSEPs compared with those of saline-treated control group, FTY720 + tacrolimus-treated group showed a significantly higher (P < 0.05) mean ampli- tude and a shorter (P < 0.05) mean latency of SSEPs compared with those of the FTY720- and tacrolimus-treated groups, no significant differences (P > 0.05) in either mean amplitude or mean latency of SSEPs between the FTY720- and tacrolimus-treated groups
column67: structure of axons and myelin
column71: only a few pathological changes in the FTY720 + tacrolimus treated group:  axons appeared as slightly oval structures, compact myelin proportional to the axon diameter, little intramyelinic vacuolization;  varying degrees of change in the other three groups after SCI: formation of swollen axonal profiles, a decrease in the number of healthy-looking, large-diameter axons, and a disruption in myelin structure,  axons appeared to have lost their round or oval shapes (most obvious in the saline-treated control group),  white matter showed overt splitting of the myelin lamellae, evident loss of myelin compaction and much intramyelinic vacuolization,  in the FTY720-treated group axons retained their round or oval shapes but there was intramyelinic vacuolization and some loss of myelin compaction,  changes in the tacrolimus-treated group were similar to those observed in the FTY720-treated group but the loss of myelin compaction was more obvious in tacrolimus-treated group
column72: anesthesia: pentobarbital (50 mg/kg, IP); euthanasia: perfused intracardially with saline followed by 2% glutaraldehyde and 4% paraformaldehyde in 0.1 M sodium cacodylate buffer
column73: results suggest that the combination of FTY720 and tacrolimus could be a potentially effective therapeutic strategy to treat SCI
